headline: Unbelted Rider In The Back Could Kill Someone In The Front
short descr: By Cheryl Jensen, FairWarning People who don‚Äôt buckle up when they ride in the rear seat because they think it‚Äôs safer back
image_caption(s): This image from a crash test shows what happens in a 35 mph collision when a passenger in the back is unbelted. The rear-seat dummy is hurled forward into the back of the front seat, forcing the driver-seat dummy into the airbag and steering wheel. Research shows that in a frontal collision, the driver is more likely to be killed if the rear-seat passenger is unbelted.
